newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Shell plans growth into electricity production.
newsitem.headline: Shell plans growth into electricity production.

text.p: Royal Dutch/Shell is to branch out into electricity production, although only in conjunction with established partners, the company said in its latest Dutch inhouse magazine.
"For Royal Dutch/Shell there is a very logical connection with our current activities," said Maarten van den Bergh, a member of the group's Committee of Managing Directors.

However, Shell does not plan to go it alone, because of the cost - on average around 750 million guilders for a 600 megawatt (MW) station - and the fact that Shell's name is not well-known in electricity production.
"With all projects, we are seeking partners. We will be also be content with a minority share of a joint venture," Van den Bergh said in Royal Dutch's "Shell Venster" magazine.

Greatest growth of electricity demand and of Shell's ambitions are in Asia. At the moment, Shell is in discussions over power station construction in the Philippines, Turkey and Peru, all in conjunction with the development of new gas fields.
Shell and Occidental are in discussions with the Philippine government to covert an unused plant into a 1,200 MW gas-fired station.
In Turkey, Shell plans to build a 2,000 MW plant in a consortium with Mitsubishi and the U.S. M.W. Kellogg Company.
In Peru, Shell is to work alongside Mobil and Petroperu in a two-year feasibility study.
"The Philippines is likely to be the first on stream. The others are at an earlier study stage," a Shell spokesman said on Wednesday.
Van den Bergh said Shell's involvement is to begin slowly.
"I think we will have done well if, in the next couple of years, we have taken part in four or five power stations," Van den Bergh told the magazine.
However, if its initial electricity forays prove successful, then Shell intends electricity to make a considerable contribution to the group's bottom line.

"If it seems that we have something substantial to offer in this sector, then our involvement will grow rapidly. Indeed it must be so. Otherwise, it doesn't amount to anything in group terms," Van den Bergh said.

Van den Bergh points out that Shell is already producing electricity at its various sites, the largest the 115 megawatt generating unit of its soon-to-be-completed Per+ complex at the Pernis refinery near Rotterdam.
